description: From Middle English sour, from Old English sūr (“sour”), from Proto-West Germanic *sūr, from Proto-Germanic *sūraz (“sour”), from Proto-Indo-European *súHros (“sour”).

Cognate with West Frisian soer, Dutch zuur (“sour”), Low German suur, German sauer (“sour”), Danish, Swedish and Norwegian sur, French sur (“sour”), Faroese súrur (“sour”), Icelandic súr (“sour, bitter”),
Polish ser (“cheese”),
Czech sýr (“cheese”),
Slovak syr (“cheese”),
Russian сырой (syroj, “raw”),
Ukrainian сири́й (syrýj, “raw”),
Old Church Slavonic сꙑръ (syrŭ, “moist, cheese”).

entries.meaning: Having an acidic, sharp or tangy taste.
Made rancid by fermentation, etc.
examples: Don't drink that milk; it's turned sour.

entries.meaning: Tasting or smelling rancid.
examples: His sour breath makes it unpleasing to talk to him.

entries.meaning: (of a person's character) Peevish or bad-tempered.
examples: He gave me a sour look.

entries.meaning: (of soil) Excessively acidic and thus infertile.
(of petroleum) Containing excess sulfur.
examples: sour gas smells like rotten eggs

entries.meaning: Unfortunate or unfavorable.
(music) Off-pitch, out of tune.
The sensation of a sour taste.
A drink made with whiskey, lemon or lime juice and sugar.
(by extension) Any cocktail containing lemon or lime juice.
A sour or acid substance; whatever produces a painful effect.
The acidic solution used in souring fabric.

verbs.description: sour (third-person singular simple present sours, present participle souring, simple past and past participle soured)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make sour.
examples: Too much lemon juice will sour the recipe.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To become sour.
examples: So the sun's heat, with different powers, / Ripens the grape, the liquor sours.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To spoil or mar; to make disenchanted.
examples: He was prudent and industrious, and so good a husbandman, that he might have led a very easy and comfortable life, had not an arrant vixen of a wife soured his domestic quiet.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To become disenchanted.
examples: We broke up after our relationship soured.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make (soil) cold and unproductive.
examples: stagnant water , which tends to sour the soil

entries.meaning: To macerate (lime) and render it fit for plaster or mortar.
(transitive) To process (fabric) after bleaching, using hydrochloric acid or sulphuric acid to wash out the lime.
